entry.title: YUM vs DNF
entry.content:
A lot has been said already about which of the two RPM-based package managers to choose from - YUM or DNF. All the ramblings must have clearly started when Jan from the DNF team proclaimed YUM is dead, long live DNF! in one of his famous rants on why Fedora 22 will have its default package manager as DNF and not the faithful old YUM. You can find that great read here. He also states the following reasons why YUM failed :

  • Broken dependency solving algorithm
  • Undocumented API
  • Inability to refactor internal functions

But, people seem to like YUM way better than DNF because it sounds better. Atleast, this thread on Reddit says so.

On the similar point of view, there are a plenty of advantages in using DNF. Few of them are :

  • Uses a successful low-level SAT solver library that SUSE has been using in production over the years
  • Downloading of the repository metadata and packages is done by Librepo, which is another component used by DNF.
  • Proven to be times faster than YUM. You can try running a list command in each.

Although, DNF seems to fit the puzzle, there are a few disadvantages that might hold it back :

  • Its a Work In Progress. The DNF team is working hard in porting all the legacy stuff of YUM to DNF. This might take some time.
  • Hogs bandwidth. Silently downloading metadata information in the background. Although, this can be tweaked and disabled in the configuration file, it poses to be a problem. You can read more about this issue here where the author states why he prefers YUM over DNF.
  • DNF Plugin API isn’t a fully baked product. Currently, the DNF API doesn’t support reading command line arguments supplied in the CLI.

In conclusion, if performance is a concern, DNF is the way to go.
